reviewText: The North Star, 1943 filmThis begins in a small village in Russia. We see horse-drawn vehicles (as in some parts of the USA) and the lives of the people. The radio brings the news. Children go to school. The people celebrate, June 22 is the traditional Mid-Summer's Day. They are all happy on this holiday. [Note the simple wood doors.] A group walks on their journey. [Note the outdoor stalls for cows.] This group sleeps on the grass. They get a ride on the farm wagon, and sing again. The man in uniform sees something in the sky: many airplanes. Then a bomb falls! People are wounded or killed. Airplanes shoot at the village. The news tells of the invasion by Germany. One group will go to the hills to be armed guerillas, others will stay behind and destroy crops, animals, and houses to keep them from the enemy, Can the armed services be supplies with ammunition? They save the guns."Travel by night, stay in the woods." People have to prevent their property from being stolen. "Another burning village!" They use a fire engine to try to put out the fire at some houses. A woman who doesn't talk has her arm and leg broken! Guerillas attack German troops. A bomber attacks German troops but is shot up. It then crashes into the tanks! Young children are bled to provide fresh blood! The German doctor explains their needs. Guerillas plan an attack on motorcycles as a distraction in the night. They take casualties. The guerillas plan an attack on the gasoline depot. Next the guards. Mounted riders attack too. The children are rescued. `I'm sorry for that." Dr. Karin stops two doctors from doing their work. Will this be the last war once people can make a better world? [Does human nature and society ever change?]This starts out like a musical then shifts into drama about the horrors of the war on the Eastern Front. Were there better movies about the resistance in WW II?
Title: N/A

reviewText: Gregory Pecks first film. A gritty study of behind the lines Russian actions during the war. Even years afterwards it is still a fine war movie. One of the things I liked best was seeing Gewrman tanks that looked a lot like, German tanks. Didn't see that again until Kelly's Heros.

reviewText: North Star a fictional  Soviet Village on the edge of the Polish/German Border.  Life could not be more peaceful or serene for townspeople who are so happy that they often have occasion to break into song.  And in this village all the songs are by Aaron Copland and Ira Gershwin.  Far from being the "Evil Empire" of the Regan era, the villagers here are boisterous children, loving parents, devoted friends and neighbors.  All of them get some opportunity to express how much they love each other and their nation.  This bucolic bliss is rudely shattered when the German's begin their blitzkrieg invasion of the region in the Summer of 1941.  The village bands together to fight off the tanks and planes of the enemy with horse cavalry and ingenuity.  The only hope for the town to repel the invaders is a cache of arms and munitions being delivered by some local teenagers.For its historical value this really is a must see movie.  And if you can find it in the 2.99 bin at the video store, I would urge you to buy it and have a showing with all of the history buffs you know in attendance.  Some of my favorite points are :*The complete glossing over of the Soviet-German Non-Aggression pact or 1939*The movie mentions that the Germans have occupied Poland but never makes mention of the fact that Russia immediately occupied the other half of Poland thus cutting the German's spoils in half.* Officially the Soviet Union was a nation of atheists.  The movie makers skirt around this potential fault by having some of the characters assume a praying type of posture (head down hands clasped together) as they silently work up the strength to make the needed sacrifices.Other than as a period piece this movie has nothing to recommend it.  The script is so flat that I recall once reading that Lillian Hellman tried unsuccessfully to have her name removed from the credits.  The characters are wooden and lifeless manikins who mouth only patriotic platitudes.  The songs would also stand a better chance if they too were more than just grist for the propaganda mill.What is  great is to see so many Hollywood stars doing there bit for the war effort.  Ann Baxter,  Dana Andrews,  Walter Huston, Farley Granger, and Jane Winters (later to win fame as Josephine the Plumber) are all featured.  They sing and dance and cavort around in regional costumes.  In fact every effort is made to ensure that we are left with the opinion that except for the odds names and the quaint outfits, the kids of North Star are just like the kids back in the good old USA.  A script like this one makes it very easy for me to believe that Dana Andrews and Farley Granger could be the boy next door !
summary: When the "evil empire"  was the good guy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Samuel Goldwyn's excellent but now almost forgotten wartime drama THE NORTH STAR was scripted by Lillian Hellman and directed by Lewis Milestone. William Cameron Menzies was associate producer, Aaron Copland scored some fine Ukrainian-like music with Ira Gershwin providing lyrics. Hellman and Copland were both Oscar-nominated for their contributions as was cinematographer James Wong Howe. The picture received 6 Academy nods in all.At first blush this appears to be a jolly Goldwyn musical. Happy peasants in traditional garb sing, dance and strum 3-string balalaikas. They play harmonicas and squeezeboxes whenever the opportunity arises. It's during one of these picturesque interludes that a stark future suddenly looms in the form of the German Blitzkrieg.Bearded Walter Brennan and a slow-moving open horsecart full of kids enjoy a sunny morning filled with smiles, affection and song until a frightening drone is heard overhead. V-formation Luftwaffe planes suddenly bomb their country road. Terrorized people flee into a ditch, but not all make it safely. One man is crushed by a fallen telephone pole and a young left-handed child loses that arm and soon after, his life.WWII has come crashing in on their little village. A quiet place that's changed little over the centuries is suddenly and violently thrust into the jaws of a modern armored beast. No matter the outcome, these peoples' lives will never be the same. Men armed with pistols and rifles quickly form a cavarly brigade to battle pantzers, machine guns and artillery. The women, children and old folks left behind vow to fight their invaders to the death.The enemy shows no mercy. Children are strafed in the streets. Others will have their life's blood stolen so wounded Germans might survive operations. Systematic and murderous destruction is appalling, yet these brave people DO fight back! It's a desperate, unforgettable scene in one of the finest war films ever made. Highly recommended."North Star" is also available as part of Mill Creek's outstandingHOLLYWOOD LEGENDS 50 MOVIE PACK.Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 imdb viewer poll rating.(6.1) The North Star (1943) - Anne Baxter/Dana Andrews/Walter Huston/Walter Brennan/Ann Harding/Jane Withers/Farley Granger/Erich von Stroheim/Dean Jagger
summary: "The Earth belongs to us, the people, if we fight for it. And we will fight for it!"

reviewText: There were two different versions of this film.The North Star(1943)About a small Russian village and the folks who live there in 1941 invaded by the nazis.Good Cast,Dana Andrews,Anne Baxter,Walter Huston,Ann Harding,Walter Brennan,Farley Granger,Jane Withers,etcEric Von Stronheim is especially good as a German medic who uses children for blood transfussions to wounded soldiers.As twilight settled on WW2,Joe Stalin was no longer our friend,the Korean War went into full swing,the Cold War began this film was quite an embarasement.In 1957,the film was cut of its pro Soviet views and rereleased as Armormed Attack.The 1957 version is about a town in Europe being invaded by the nazis and the communist sympathys cut out as it ends with the Hungarian 1956 Revolution.This DVD is marked Armormed Attack,but its The North Star.Be careful if, like me you were looking for version #2.

reviewText: "North Star" while made in 1943, in the midst of World War 2, was way too corny and predictable to be the least bit entertaining.  It guess it served to incite viewers against the Nazi war machine and was successful in doing that.Scripted by Lillian Hellman, the movie surrounds the pastoral Russian village of North Star.  The last day of school heralds the onset of the summer vacation.  The town is in a festive mood.  Students Dana Andrews, Anne Baxter, Farley Granger and Jane Withers are planning a hiking trip to Kiev.  Soon after they embark the village is overrun by Nazi invaders.  The men of fighting age flee into the surrounding woods to campaign in guerilla warfare led by Dean Jagger.Walter Huston playing eminent physician Dr. Kurin, the town elder, tries to hold the Nazis at bay.  Erich von Stroeheim plays an apparently humane German doctor who has set up a hospital within the village.  His aim to to tranfuse precious blood needed for wounded soldiers from the children of the village, killing them in the process.The village mobilizes to fight the Nazis and stop the atrocities being committed.  The venerable Walter Brennan plays Karp, the wagon driver who helps the cause by smuggling in guns to help the villagers in their battle.Director Lewis Milestone did his patriotic duty however "North Star" had no where near the anti-war sentiment and effect of his superb "All Quiet on the Western Front".  The flick was little more than a transparent bit of propaganda.

reviewText: Leo B. Mayer cranked out a lot of these silly films for public consumption to convince people in the U.S. or the rightness of the WAR EFFORT.  They are silly maudlin films appealing mostly to the women left on the homefront who held down men's jobs.  Of course the majority of men were in uniform fighting or in uniform to support the WAR!  In retrospect Amerikans obeyed and followed the hype into battle for in truth we were fighting an enemy whose aims were total domination and oppression of the World as part of a New German Empire.  But, we must remember these films built a mentality which persists to this day and is deleterious to our own individual and corporate freedoms established by the Constitution!

reviewText: "The North Star" is a star studded 1943 war film produced by Sam Goldwyn for RKO and written by Lillian Hellman. It was part of Roosevelt's propaganda to promote his Russian allies who were taking the brunt of the war at the time the film was made. The focus of the film is the Ukraine resistance fighters.The film stars Anne Baxter, Dana Andrews, Walter Huston, Walter Brennan, Dean Jagger, Farley Granger and Erich von Stroheim.Anne Baxter had just completed a good supporting role opposite Joseph Cotton  in Orson Welles' "The Magnificent Ambersons" (1942) when she got top billing for "North Star". After this she won the Oscar and the Golden Globe for "The Razor's Edge" (1946) and was nominated for an Oscar for her role as the ambitious Eve Harrington in "All About Eve" (1950). In 1956 she appeared as Queen Nefertiri in "The Ten Commandments" which is probably the peak of her career.Dana Andrews appeared in over 100 films, including memorable roles in "The Westerner" (1941), "The Ox Bow Incident" (1943), "Laura" (1944) and "The Best Years of Our Lives" (1946). He plays a young air force studentWalter Huston was churning out films in the 1930s, sometimes as many as 8 in a year. His performances were relatively undistinguished, even if some of the films (e.g., "Gabriel Over the White House") were hits. Huston got better as he got older, and he was nominated for an Oscar in 1937 ("Dodsworth") and 1942 ("Devil and Daniel Webster"). The same year this film came out he was nominated again ("Yankee Doodle Dandy") and won in 1949 for "Treasure of the Sierra Madre", just before he died in 1950. Huston plays the good Russian Dr. Kurin.Walter Brennan won 3 Oscars for Best Supporting Actor ("Come and Get it" in 1936, "Kentucky" in 1938, and "The Westerner" in 1941) and was nominated for his work in "Sergeant York" (1941). We know him best for his Emmy nominated role in the TV series "The Real McCoys", and his film comedies ("The Over the Hill Gang") or as the grumpy side kick Stumpy in "Rio Bravo", but he was equally capable of playing the villain, as he showed in "The Westerner" (1940), "My Darling Clementine" (1946), and again In "How the West Was Won" (1962). Brennan plays Karp, a peasant,  and he does such a great job that he is virtually unrecognizable, either physically or by listening for his voice.Brennan and Huston had worked together in "Swamp Water" (1941) where Brennan got top billing. So the chance to shoot Brennan in this film was therapeutic for Huston. Interestingly enough Huston would go on to play a similar role in "The Dragon Seed" (1944), this time set in China.Dean Jagger is best known for his TV role as Principal Vane in "Mr. Novak" for which he was twice nominated for an Emmy (1964, 1965), and for his Oscar winning role in "Twelve O'Clock High" (1949). He brought a grace and charm to his more than 100 roles including "Bad Day at Black Rock" (1955) and "Vanishing Point" (1971). Jagger plays a resistance leader.Erich von Stroheim plays the evil German doctor. Von Stroheim was a famous German silent film director ("Greed", "The Merry Widow", "The Lost Squadron"), but he got into too many arguments when the talkie era started, and he turned to acting. He had plenty of experience playing the evil German soldier in the silent era ("The Hun Within", "The Heart of Humanity") so he transitioned easily into his role for this film. Von Stroheim is perhaps best remembered for his Oscar nominated role as the film director Max Von Mayerling in "Sunset Blvd" (1950).This was Farley Granger's film debut. He had a busy, if undistinguished career, appearing in more than 50 films and for awhile, as a headliner. Some of his best work was done in Hitchcock's  "Rope" (1948)  and "Strangers on a Train" (1951).Jane Withers plays Clavdia, a friend of Baxter. Withers is best known to us today as "Josephine the Plumber" from the commercials in the 60s and 70s, but she was, in fact, one of the most popular stars of the 30s and 40s.Carl Benton Reid plays Andrews' father, one of the resistance leaders. Reid was a great character actor. He made a big splash in his first film opposite Bette Davis in "The Little Foxes" (1941) and went on to appear in more than 50 films before transitioning to TV where he continued to play many parts, often a loud mayor or a heavy in a western.Martin Kosleck plays the incompetent German doctor. Kosleck was so adept at playing Nazis that he has the distinction of playing Hermann Goebbels more times than any other actor (5). A German born refugee from the Nazis, he played Goebbels for the first time in 1939 ("Confessions of a Nazi Spy").The film was commercially and critically successful. It was nominated for 6 Oscars (Writing, Recording, Music, Cinematography, Special Effects, and Art Direction), and deservedly so. The film is beautifully shot with individual scenes that are of the same quality as GWTW.  James Wong Howe received his fourth nomination for this film, and he would receive 5 more nominations and 2 wins ("Hud" and "The Rose Tatoo") in the future, making him one of the most acknowledged cinematographers in film history.The music is inspirational throughout. Aaron Copeland received his third Oscar nomination for his work, and a few years later he would win for "The Heiress" (1949)Lillian Hellman did the screenplay. This was her second Oscar nomination, having earned one in 1942 for "The Little Foxes" (in which Carl Benton Reid made his screen debut) which was adapted from her own play. Hellman's other plays include "The Children's Hour" (1934) and "Toys in the Attic" (1960). Hellman was fond of left wing causes, and her lover, famed author Dashiell Hammett was an avowed Communist Party member. Hammett and Hellman worked together on the screenplay "Watch on the Rhine" that starred Bette Davis and Paul Lukas.Despite the accolades, by 1947, with the winds of war changing, the film was named "subversive" by the HUAC, and it was heavily edited to remove the scenes which showed Russian communal farm life (in the first 30 minutes of the film) as attractive. In fact, it was re-issued as "Armored Attack"Leaving aside the political agenda, this is a great film with strong performances from a star studded cast, beautiful photography and music, and an excellent story line. The action sequences are well done and the special effects, for 1943, are exceptional.

reviewText: Still scary today for the hospital screen. Interesting to reflect on when this film was made, Russia was on the Allied side. They played it up. I wonder how some of these actors faired in the McCarthy era. Overall, good film. A little campy today but it does give you an insight into the feelings of the time

reviewText: It was a worker’s paradise until the Hitler’s forces invaded.  All the faults of the Stalinist state were overlooked to cast the Germans as the cruel villains they were.  There were a couple of well-known stars and a chaste love story ending with a triumph of the proletariat.  It was interesting to see how American war-time audiences got a side of politics with their entertainment.  The story was okay and the collective farm setting may be realistic, but you should watch it while keeping in mind the context of the times.  Of course everything changed after the war.  Remember Joe McCarthy?
summary: World War II Propaganda Made When the Russians Were Our Friends

reviewText: After purchasing every available copy of this film on the market, please take my advise -- DO NOT BOTHER!There is obviously no decent print of this film currently available.  Being that it was originally produced by Samuel Goldwyn and released through United Artists, one might assume that MGM/UA Home Video might hold the original negatives (since they appear to have the rights to other Goldwyn films presently).  The truth may be that no better version of this film exists, and that would be a damn shame given its historic significance and the place it held in Soviet/US relations at the time it was made.But until MGM Home Video releases this title (IF they ever do), save your bucks and download it for free off of the Internet.  The quality can't be any worse.

reviewText: A Story that ranges from great love to incredable terror, May 23, 2014By Gerald T. Westbrook "GTW" (Texas)(REAL NAME)This review is from: Self-Publishing Simplified (Paperback)The North Star (1943 film)also known in the USA asArmored AttackIntroductionThis film starts out with much joy. All of the people portrayed show great excitement with life. They also show great joy and tenderness with their family. There is much singing and dancing. Then when four of the Simonov family are sitting at their table, their radio — which has been on in the background — “reports on German troop movements on the Polish border, but their nature is unknown. It also reports that 112 Polish children died this morning as a result of excessive blood transfusions to German wounded.”However, as the movie progresses this scene gradually changes. This film is about the resistance of Ukranian villagers. They utilized guerrilla tactics against the German invaders. This film was viewed, initially, as strongly supportive of the Soviet Union, at the height of this war. In the 1950s it was remade to eliminate an idealized version of Soviet collective farms. It also included references to the 1956 Hungarian Uprising.While this is part of the Nazis invasion of the Soviet Union, Ukraine just happens to be in the way. Eventually their home village is occupied by the Nazis. The full brutality of the Nazis is shown when a German doctor — Doctor von Harden — uses the village children, once again, as a blood source for transfusions to German soldiers. Many transfusions are required and some children have so much blood taken that they die.A famous Russian doctor — Doctor Pavel Grigorich Kurin — discovers this and informs the partisans. These militia members launch a cavalry assault on the village to rescue the children. “The Russian doctor, accuses the German doctor of being worse than the convinced Nazis, because he has used his skills to support them. He then shoots him.” The peasants join together and one girl sees a future in which they will “make a free world for all men.”CastThis film has an outstanding cast. It features several members of the Pavlov family; several members of the Simonov family, three members of the Kurin family, three doctors, and others, with music by Aaron Copland.The Pavlov family featured:● Anne Baxter as Marina Pavlov;● Ann Harding as Sophia Pavlov;● Ann Carter as Olga Pavlov;● Dean Jagger as Rodion Pavlov.The Siminov family included:● Dana Andrews as Kolya Simonov;● Farley Granger as Damian Simonov;● Carl Benton Reid as Boris Simonov and● Ruth Nelson as Nadga Simonov.The Kurin family included:● Jane Withers as Claudia Kurin;● Eric Robert as Grisha Kurin;● Esther Dale as Anna Kurin;and Dr. Kurin as noted below.Medical doctors included:● Walter Houston as Dr. Pavel Grigorish Kurin;● Erich von Steinham as Dr. von Harden and● Martin Kosleck as Dr. Richter.Others:● Walter Brennan as Comrade Karp, an elderly gentleman andWhile all of these people were Ukrainians, the movie was cast for them to use the English language. Further, quotations from these characters are approximate, as no text exists. Also, at times, it is very hard to pin down who is doing the talking. In such a case, generalizations will be used.PlotIn June, 1941 Ukrainian villagers across the country are living in peace. Much joy and happiness is abundant. Comrade Karp is shown moving a huge pig in his cart. He leaves for awhile, but he and the pig comeback. He asks a question to Boris, who is under a tractor: “What seems to be the trouble Boris? His response is that it will take a better mechanic then I am to fix this tractor. Damian Simonov responds: “The patient is cured, father. It is almost new.”Comrade Karp then turns his attention to Damian. After a few words Damian asks him if he has ever been to Kiev. His answer was many times. On one of these trips I met a young lady there. She was a very pretty girl there who “lost her head over me.” Unfortunately she lost interest. Next he asked is Marina going to Kiev too? “Have you proposed to her yet?”Next we see the Pavlov family having breakfast at their table. The youngest girl in the family continues her pitch to be treated as an adult. She complains about her treatment as a youngster. Marina, her older sister, notes that she is so young. She protests and asks her father if she can’t do all the tasks that need to be done, in getting the train loaded with their farm products, and in preparing for their picnic that evening. Boris interrupts her to tell her to include: “there will be work to do.” At this time the radio from Moscow reports of the German movements on the Polish border, but their nature is unknown. It also reports that 112 Polish children died this morning as a result of massive blood transfusions to German wounded. Boris can’t believe this would be possible.Most of the children of the village have not heard this broadcast. They line up in a long school hall, standing and waiting for their teacher to dismiss them. He covers several subjects:● he first congratulates the three students who have been awarded scholarships to Kiev University;● next he notes that one of them, Damian Simonov, has taken the highest honors of any pupil in this years graduating class.● finally the senior teacher gives his farewell address to the students about to leave for the summer. He notes: “This is the summer of 1941, a solemn time. No one knows what will happen.” Then with a nod to the pianist they all start to sing a very patriotic song, with many dancing as they march behind the accordion player.Five young friends finalize their plans to travel to Kiev, the capital of the Ukraine, for a vacation. These are Marina, Sophia, and Rodion Pavlov and Kolya and Damian Simonov. Their good byes last essentially all night. Marina’s younger sister crawls into her bed and gently strokes her face. But Marina turns around and tells her “you can’t come along, you’re too young. Her reaction: I’m always too young. I’m too young for everything.”The many goodbyes are in the early morning and are long and joyful. They head out singing with Kolya, in uniform, playing his string instrument. By the end of the first day they can be seen soaking their feet in the waters of a little creek. That evening Damian and Marina and Kolya and Sophia can be seen lying side by side, with Damian exhibiting a high capability to snore. The question is asked: “Do all men make such noises?” As they head back to their walk, birds can be seen up in the trees and the power lines adding to the spirit of beauty and joy.Soon Comrade Karp appears in his cart, along with several other carts. I’ll give you all a ride to the crossroads. It is a good time for a ride. The two girls initially insist they must walk. Finally, Sophia climbs aboard. And another accordion player starts to play.However, it is not long before they start to hear strange noises. It must be from planes, but never so many. Then they start to see explosions in the near distance. The explosions get closer annd closer. Soon, to their horror, they are suddenly attacked by German Stukas. Kolya orders everyone to get down, we are being bombed. Get in the ditch he shouts. Leave the horses and get into the ditch. When the raid is over Kolya carries Marina out of the ditch. Both are not injured, but a small baby boy is hurt badly and bleeding profusely. Soon Comrade Karp tells them the boy is gone.They return to their village, only to discover the Stukas have also reappeared and strife the area with their dive bombing tactics. Boris Simonov tells his fellow villagers that we have good reason to know our country is now at war as 11 were killed and 30 injured by this attack. Boris — a big, burly man, and probably the unofficial leader of the village — recommends that the villagers must split into two groups:● All able body men must move to the hills immediately, to become guerilla fighters.● The second group, which he notes will be the hardest, must stay behind, where they will destroy most things, to leave nothing for the German sodiers to use. They must also live with the Germans and also must spy on the soldiers where ever possible. Once a week one of the villagers must meet with the first group, bringing supplies as well as any spy information. Many peasants, on horses, vote on this plan, and overwhelming approve itBoris Simonov outlines his immediate plans. I will go immediately to Commander Petrov’s garrison to get the guns. Soon he meets with Comrade Petrov, who tells Boris that the German’s are advancing rapidly across our territory. By nightfall there won’t be a highway free of their guns, trucks and tanks. Your best chance is to stick to the back roads. Boris however, concludes he doesn’t have that much time. My guerillas need the guns now. Boris climbs aboard his big truck and heads out. But soon his convoy is attacked. Boris is barely able to climb out of his overturned truck. Boris orders them to get the guns out. They get them unloaded and take them to the far end of the street. However, Boris, who has been wounded, can’t go on any further, falls to the ground He passes away. Boris Simonov is buried on the spot.The villagers load the guns onto wagons and are instructed to travel at night. Koyla also announces that he has to get to the closest airport. Soon after his departure the Nazis arrive in a limousine. Many villagers can be seen rushing to set fires, when they can. The commander finds the massive fires set by the villagers. The Nazis have the tools and troops to fight such fires, which they do. Soon, the commander is able to ask “who is responsible for this burning and destruction? Where are the younger men?” Another limousine arrives with three doctors in it. One of the doctors asks if the hospital has been destroyed. The answer is no, so he orders that all the wounded German soldiers in his vehicles be helped into the hospital. Before any one can answer the initial commander reads from a small notebook that they have discovered, that flags Boris Simonov as the “leader” of the villagers. Is he here? With no answer he asks where is his family. He goes on: “you who have burned this village and hence have shown that you are enemies of the German army. We punish our enemies, severely.” The commander asks: I want to know where he is, how many men he has with him, and how much ammunition he has. Where is the wife of this Boris Simonov? She finally and proudly identifies herself, but refuses to answer any of his questions. “The doctor in charge, doctor von Harden, instructs the troops to take her inside. Soon horrible screams emerge from the hospital. The commander notes her right arm and right leg have been broken. You should advise your people to give information when they are asked.” Next, Doctor Kurin charges von Harden, that even though you are a doctor, you’re able to tolerate such action. von Harden responds that “in this new order of ours one does not necessarily approve of all the steps that must be taken.”The next scene shows a squad of German soldiers on motorcycles. As they get close to the truck convoy one of the dogs in the convoy starts to bark. Three soldiers are ordered to inspect the area. Comrade Karl instructs Marina to get the horses while he and the youngster keep their eyes on the soldiers. One soldier, on seeing the convoy attempts to throw a grenade, but Karl opens fire and hits two of the soldiers, while the young lad hits one.The convoy pulls out, passing a German ambulance that was heading to the shooting site. Dr. Pavel Grigorish Kurin, and his wife, Anna now hears planes, but discover they are from the Ukranian Air-force. Koyla is shown, aboard one of the planes, as barely awake as they approach their target. He takes over the role as the bombardier, but the Germans fire is deadly and soon both the pilot and co-pilot are killed. Koyla discovers he must take over as the pilot. He is still the bombardier and starts a diving run, but his plane crashes — either by the German fire, or deliberately — the tall trees and quickly into the ground, with flames breaking out.The next scene shows Dr. Kurin, a famous Russian pathologist and his wife sitting in a waiting room at the hospital. A nurse comes in and reports many of the children will have to give blood tonight. Dr. Kurin gets up and inspects where the children are located. Overcome by outrage he grabs a scallop and attempts to stab Dr. von Harden. He is stopped, but asks: ‘how can a man of medicine take blood from children and bleed them white.” Suddenly a young boy staggers forward into Kurin’s arms. “This boy needs help. May I?” von Harden’s answer is “of course, then equally suddenly Dr. Richter storms in and demands to know why von Harden is not going to have this man arrested. Dr. von Harden’s response: “If you wish to be a warrior you must take chances with you’re life. Dr. Kurin is a famous man of science. He is of no danger to us.”Next we see Dr. Kurin, with a boy in his arms, wading away from the hospital. Soon a guard calls out, but recognizes Kurin and the boy. It is one of the boys from the village. You recognized him Comrade, take him to the emergency aid station.Meantime Damien and Marina and others are working on collecting information useful in their plans. They count 40 trucks and about 15 motorcycles. Next they count how fast they are moving. “When we get done here Comrade Karp will know that we have done our work.” Marina looks at Damien and notes: “your face has changed. He responds and so has yours.” She clearly wants to come with him as he heads back to the guerilla camp. He notes that “she could sleep on my shoulder, which would be very tender.” Then Damien asks Marina, very gently if he could kiss her. And so he does, very gently, for the very first time.Damien reviews his plans: “I’m going through the woods. As the motorcycles come around the turn, I’m going to fire. That will stop the column. You will be ready to leave.” As the firing starts you will take the wagons across the road. They will not be looking at you. They will be busy with us. Right Comrade Karp? They will be busy with us.Next we see Damian make his way through the woods, with rifle in hand. Then we see Comrade Karp tell Marina: “When you hear the firing, go across as fast as you can and remember to leave a little room for me to cross next to you.” Soon Marina asks Grisha, where is Claudia. Grisha responds that she has gone. In turn Marina responds: I’ll go find her. Grisha’s reaction: You must not go after her. You must let her alone. I have seen her face. She must work this out herself. On a key hill, Claudia is almost paralyzed with fear. Help me she pleads. “Make me do something right, the way everybody else does. Keep me from being so frightened. Keep me from crying, please.” Then she wipes a tear from her face and starts to walk towards the potential area of combat.Damian now works his way through woods. He can barely hear the motor-cycles, as the truck convoy passes. Damian and Marina both kneel and wait, and soon both aim and fire at the motor-cycle soldiers. They run, then a rocket is fired to provide light. Damian grabs Marina and they run. The trucks back up and soon the woods are full of Nazis, and ultimately they start to fire at these two. Damian and Marina are split apart, but start to fire back. But Sophia is hit and falls. Comrade Karp councils Marina to not go to her. Wait a minute then cross. The crossing is madeDamian also hs been hit. He asks Marina: “Where are we? What time is it?” She answers five. In turn he asks “morning or afternoon?” His last question startles her, but she hugs him immediately. He reaches up with his right arm and touches her face. Next we see Comrade Karp moving his wagon, with Damian and Marina in the back. He is followed by several other wagons.Several comments follow in rapid order:● All right, all right. It does me know good to lie. Men with rocks and clubs are not good against machine guns. But know that there will be five men to a gun;● Our time has come to fight. You all Know it, and all say it;● This may be the last time we ride down a hill;● All right, saddle your horses;● Take up your watch at the pine grove;● We see guerilla lads are here with the gasoline. Rush them down to the north cornfield. Prey that they arrive on time.Next we see a scene of a Nazi guard atop a tall command and machine gun post. This is followed by a scene of the guerrillas on horseback. Selected men are told to dismount.Again we see several comments in rapid order:● Run to the school yard and run fast;● Barricade it as soon as you get in;● You know the plan. Each group knows what to do. The groups then separate.Again we see Nazi troops march by. After a period the guerillas crawl from unde a truck, and through farm fields. As more Nazis pass, other guerillas move across the water. Some climb into a Nazi station, through a trap door, and into a room that is inside the command post. Very soon they open the door and drag a Nazi into the inner room. They knock him out and strip off his clothing. One guerilla now looks like one of the Nazi soldiers, and he walks out onto the platform, but avoiding real Nazis. The other guerillas lock the door, and one says: ‘And now to the gasoline. They pour large amounts of it into the water below. Another guerilla moves out onto the platform and immediately tosses a grenade into the water. The flames spread rapidly. This essentially drives the Nazis away from this machine gun.The villagers see this and note: “they are fighting for our village.” Wagons are pulled into action, but a machine gun opens up. “Our children are here.” Now the guerillas move out. “Now we are fighting for our village.” I will take you, and they charge into the village and attack another gun placement and head for the school. They have come to fight. Some are shot down by machine gun fire, but soon carts are pulled into the scene. The senior women awake to the situation. They welcome the carts and the weapons are handed out.Gisha is hugged by his mother and Marina barely is able to control herself as her mother crawls toward her. More guerillas are shot down or fall off their horses, but are able to counter attack, with many grenades tossed. Gun post after gun post are attacked. Comrade Karp is also able to rescue many children and get them into carts.The scene shifts back to the hospital room, where the surgeons can be seen at work. Dr. Kurin is invited in by von Harden. He notes; “you do not like Dr. Richter. And I don’t like do not like much of what I have done for the past eight years.” Kurin responds so you do not like bleeding children to their death. He asks: Did the boy die? They took too much blood. I am sorry for these children. I am sorry for many things. Kurin responds: “men who do murder - - -. You see Dr Harden you are wrong about many things. I am a man who cant stand your behavior then shoots him on sight.The scene shifts again as the carts are drawn away Dr. Kurin helps where he can in one of the carts. Our village is gone, but there will be another someday. Marina adds: “They will make this the last one. The Earth belongs to us the people and we will fight for it.ConclusionsOne can only prey that Marina is right. The Ukraine saw much bloodshed in both wars. And for World War II it saw bloodshed at both the start and the end of this war. Today it faces more challenges with Russia and its leader Vladimir Putin. Putin is an ex KGB leader who exhibits an interest in seeing Russia restored to a position of dominance in Europe. One can only prey that he is not successful in this goal.I grew up in a Canadian city — Saskatoon Saskatchewan — that had many Ukraine families. As such several of my friends were Ukrainians. One of these, A Ramon Hnatyshyn, grew up as one of my youngest friends. As we grew older we played high school basketball together. However we separated a bit in university as he went to the Law school whereas I went into engineering. His law degree got him into politics and after many offices he finally was appointed as Governor General of Canada. This soon led to a visit to the Ukraine, a statue on a well traveled city park and a museum of Ukraine history.
summary: From great love to incredable terror
Title: N/A

reviewText: Samuel Goldwyn's THE NORTH STAR is a prestigiously mounted film about a small village in the Ukraine attacked by the Nazis during the Barbarossa campaign during WWII. The film demonstrates how the men and women of our ally Russia worked as a cohesive force to fight off the Germans. An impressive cast includes Dana Andrews, Anne Baxter, Dean Jagger, Farley Granger, Erich von Stroheim, Walter Huston, Walter Brennan and Jane Withers. The list of other filmmakers is also very impressive. They include director Lewis Milestone, screenwriter Lillian Hellman, legendary cinematographer James Wong Howe and distinguished composer Aaron Copland and producer William Cameron Menzies. That's quite a list. Aaron Copland, James Wong Howe and Lillian Hellman were all nominated for the Academy Award for their work on this film. This film puts the Russians in a good light as romantic combatants meeting the brutal and barbaric Germans in this skillfully constructed piece of propaganda. It is an interesting to see the American perception of the Soviets from this film made during WWII.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Certainly an idyllic fantasy without any accuracy! By 1941 Ukraine had already been devastated by agrarian reforms and the Declaration of Ukrainian Independence was 30 June 1941. Aside from the historical inaccuracies and the ridiculous portrayal of Ukrainian culture, are there any redeeming features? Possibly. There is that romantic dramatization that imbued this timeline in cinematography.  In 1943 and later it was considered as a pro-Russian propaganda film by some. Certainly an odd choice of location for that purpose. The cast is well known as is the original producer. Recommended for those who enjoy this genre.Note: Any resemblance to actual people and history is accidental!

reviewText: This movie doesn't even resemble reality, other than the fact that some Teutonic types did indeed invade the Ukraine in 1941. Where does one even begin?First, the merry, carefree life under dear Comrade Stalin. Oh yes, life was a joy, uncomplicated by the Kulaks (who were nicely done away with by the NKVD) or excessive food (but that problem was being resolved, now that the famine had left the UkSSR with a million less peasants). Everyone just sang and danced...A pilot who is hanging out with a girl says that "she just doesn't fit in." She finds this amusing. In reality, she would be terrified: to be different was to invite a visit by the secret police. A few years earlier to be the SAME would be an invitation for a visit by the secret police. Wasn't communism wonderful?Where were the obligatory portraits of Uncle Joe? The party leaders who bullied everyone? The absurd application of Marxist doctrine to everything from milking to auto mechanics?Really? Partisan bands being formed on Day 2 of the invasion? The NKVD would have shot them as being defeatist. Not only that, but many of the Ukrainians fought AGAINST the Soviets following the war.Of course, it was wartime but the state of the USSR was known long before this movie was made. Only FDR could have ordered such a movie made. Only Hollywood could make the communists look like Americans.
summary: Hollywood's version of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic

reviewText: I was really surprised by this film in that it is pure WWII gold (i.e. Soviet people are good and Nazi's are bad). No mention is made in any shape or form to the millions killed by Stalin and the irony of it all is that this film is set in the Ukraine; site of the Soviet ordered famine which killed millions of Kulaks (Ukrainian farmers); but then again why would it (Stalin was our ally)?I was also `very' surprised that Aaron Copeland did the music for this film. There are several actors who went on to earn great fame after this B-WWII propaganda film such as: Anne Baxter, Dana Andrews, Walter Huston, Walter Brennan, Jane Withers, Farley Granger, and many others all of whom became major stars. I highly recommend this film just for the historical (hollywood that is) value - thus earning the 3 stars (if it were not for the above factiods - I'd give it two stars).
summary: Nice piece of PRO Soviet WWII Propaganda

reviewText: Released in 1943, the film is set in '41. The tedious 20-minute opening establishes 1) a group of friends are excited to be going on a trip to Kiev  2) Germans are at the Polish border  3) the harmoniously-run Ukrainian village depicted spends its energy dealing with its surplus of both food and time by dancing and singing and having a party...oh yeah, and talking about the upcoming trip. About 30 minutes in, something HAPPENS. Things improve slightly, when Eric von Stroheim shows up.Dana Andrews, known for - notorious for? - his devilishly effective subtle acting style was in fact a trained opera singer. The opportunity to sing in an Aaron Copeland musical must have been his only inducement for participating in this waste of war-time materiel. Watched it on Instant-view with Prime. Speech at end says she wants freedom without war, and will FIGHT for it! I'm double checking the definition of irony. Extra star for having the good taste to get some GREAT names in cast and crew.
summary: A Dull Musical about Vague Happy Communist Stuff
Title: N/A

reviewText: Before the Second World War, Hollywood often took ambivalent looks at Stalin's Russia.  However, when Josef Vissarionovich and FDR found themselves on the same side following Hitler's invasion of the USSR, Hollywood felt little compunction about presenting Russia through a glowing visage.  In THE NORTH STAR, director Lewis Milestone spent no less than the first third of the film showing Your Typical Ukrainian Village as populated by happy, singing, dancing supporters of Moscow, which would later be revealed in real life as bitter irony when the West realized that Stalin would deliberately starve millions of Ukrainians merely to eliminate potential sources of discord.  Some of Hollywood's biggest names of the era took part speaking midwestern English under Soviet names: Dana Andrews, Anne Baxter, Walter Brennan, and Dean Jagger.  The happy lives of the villagers are disrupted forever when the first wave of Stuka dive bombers begin their strafing runs.  Within hours of this aerial assault, the local commissars organize an armed resistance of partisans who take a common oath of never to surrender that must have reminded the audience of similar oaths taken by Washington's rag tag army at Valley Forge.  Erich Von Stroheim is the monacled bad guy, the very personification of the educated "good" German who may have had mental reservations about genocide but had no problem with carrying out his orders to kill innocent children. Walter Hudson is the conscience of the community, a doctor who takes a terrible revenge on the Germans at the final reel.NORTH STAR was clearly intended as a propaganda piece.  It was necessary at the time to present Communism in a favorable light.  NORTH STAR was so successful at this that a decade later, the House UnAmerican Activities Committee found it to be  no less than a treasonous piece of celluloid commie trash. A butchered version called ARMORED ATTACK was released which omitted these offending scenes of Soviet heroism.  As harshly as Milestone depicted the Nazis, the shattering reality of their utter determination to exterminate what the Nazis called "Unterermenschen" (sub humans) rendered Von Stroheim's bloodletting and arm breaking as relatively mild. NORTH STAR emerges as an entertaining early counterweight to RED DAWN, a film that exactly manages to reverse Milestone's moral compass.  Not many films managed to present or even to try to present the Russians as the good guys.  NORTH STAR succeeds in doing so.
summary: The Russians as the Good Guys
Title: N/A

reviewText: Kudos to Communist American playwright Lillian Hellman for absurdly cheerful portrayal of Ukrainian peasants at the time when Stalin had starved millions with forced collectivization.  Their perfectly clean straw-roofed village with fat geese and plump people in Tolstoy era peasants costumes had me and my friend laughing heartedly from the beginning.  Or is it heartless laughter behind Hellman's WWII script commissioned by RKO studios after an order by FDR to portray the soviet peoples in a positive light once they became American allies against the nazis?Have you seen The Twelve Chairs by Mel Brooks?  The opening scene of Russian peasants singing "Hope for the best but prepare for the worst" is a better portrayal of the desperate lives of all peasants in Europe.  Most Hollywood Jews despised them after centuries of pogroms ("like thunder" attacks).I have to say that Aaron Copeland's efforts with singing and dancing and lyrics could rival a Saturday Night Live send off of Russian propaganda. Bi love how there was a whole row of John Deere tractors in one small village!  Everyone spoke perfect English until the Nazis arrived, with typically harsh German accents.  The soviet film version of a German takeover if a village shows tanks and motorcycles arriving and burning down everything in sight, including a barn full of the village inhabitants.  This film is called "Come and See" and it is gruesome.The first half hour is delightfully false and sunny until nazi planning has the village bombed by airplanes.  Was it all those valuable tractors tempting them?From this point on the film is full if grim killing and children getting bloodletting for soldiers plasma.  When in postwar editing the first 30 minutes were cut as communist propaganda, the film began with the strafing.Truly atrociously bad portrayal of the USSR is to be recommended for viewers interested in wartime propaganda, fake Russian folk songs and dances, Lillian Hellman, Anne Baxter, Jane Withers, tractors, Nazis, and Hollywood backlot perfect villages set on fire.It WAS entertaining hence the four stars.Bravo FDR!
summary: Delightful mockery of Communist rural misery in 1941 Ukraine

reviewText: I stumbled upon this movie written by Lillian Hellman- one of my favorites- and couldn't stop watching, probably for all the wrong reasons.The plot is fine, but it portrays life under Stalin as pretty darn wonderful, and I imagine this is because it was made with the help of the good old US of A back when we were trying to bolster morale by portraying our allies as really good guys.Needless to say, they weren't. And watching this story with the truth of the situation known gave it a haunting and kind of sad quality.Also, this is one of the movies named as subversive by witnesses before the House Committee on Un-American Activities (HUAC) in October, 1947, which is even crazier.Good performances by Dana Andrews et al, this is worth a look!

reviewText: When the Second World war seemed lost to the Germans in Europe. While the USSR stood against the brunt of the nazi barbarians total war against them. This American film was made. Had to,for the sake of their futures in film. Make anti Communist flicks.Are very good here including Walter Huston and Dana Andrews. Bravely defending their back lot Ukrainian villge. Still stirring with excellent direction from Lewis Milestone. And a teffific script from Mrs Dashiell Hammett, Lillian Hellman.Two fine and talented Reds the rabid US right wing failed to destroy.The film is worth seeing on a number of counts. Perhaps most importantly as a history lesson.

reviewText: This was actually a well-produced film, but it was also clearly an attempt at pro-Soviet propaganda at a time when the U.S. was allied with the U.S.S.R. against Nazi Germany.But today, knowing what we know about Stalin and Russia, events even freely admitted by Russian authorities today, all makes this film sadly outdated and historically laughable.The Soviet show-trials, in which high-ranking Communists were tortured into making ridiculous confessions, all come across as looking noble and honest.  Even Soviet Russia's 1939-40 Winter War against Finland is defended, with Finnish General (and hero) Mannerheim labelled by the American ambassador as a "friend of Hitler."But the ultimate insult to reality is in how mass-murderer Stalin (a genuine "friend of Hitler" in '39 & '40) is portrayed as a wise and honest leader, much to be admired and trusted.Again, I understand why they made this film during the war, when our government was trying to make the American people feel friendly toward our then-ally Russia.  But watching this one today is like watching the pro-Nazi documentary, "Triumph of the Will," only this one is much more clumsy in its propaganda-driven, pro-Stalin message.  It's almost embarrassing to watch today!
summary: What a piece of Marxist crap!

reviewText: This movie fascinates for the same reason that "Triumph of the Will" or "Alexander Nevsky" fascinates -- because it shows us what WWII-era totalitarian propaganda looked like.  What distinguishes this movie from the others, however, is that this one came from Hollywood, not from Stalin or Hitler.The historian Robert Conquest said "The North Star" whitewashes Stalin's Russia even more dishonestly than Stalin's own film industry would have been capable of doing.  No Soviet audience, after Stalin's forced starvations and mass murders, would have taken this movie's idyllic portrayal of Ukrainian life seriously.The film shows the degree to which the Communist Party really did influence the American film industry in the 1940's.  The writer, Lillian Hellman, was an avowed admirer of Stalin.  She did her best to mislead Americans about the Stalin purges and show-trials of the 1930's; to keep America out of the war against Hitler during the two years when Stalin and Hitler were allies; and then to encourage America to enter the war when Stalin and Hitler became enemies.
